pullRequest.body:
Tired of getting your PRs rejected by CI because of a long line?  These days are over!

The new `longLine` linter will highlight long lines, so your PRs will always be green!

:smile: 

Besides adding the linter, the PR removes the code for the older `TextBased` linter
and adds a few `set_option linter.longLine false`s in test files and in a single reference in `Mathlib.Data.QPF.Multivariate.Basic`.

---

- [ ] depends on: #15104
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

- [ ] depends on: #15107 removing a long line that sneaked in after the first batch
- [ ] depends on: #15111 linting the tests

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [1af3519310](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15097/commits/1af3519310f4a6e1184688d7ec51a47ea2aabfa0)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.Lint | 3 | 4 | +1 (+33.33%) |
| Mathlib.Data.QPF.Multivariate.Basic | 489 | 490 | +1 (+0.20%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 4018 files with changed transitive imports: this is too many to display!

</details>

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ getLinterHash`
`+ longLineLinter`
`- lineLengthLinter`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>
I went ahead and shortened the lines exceeding 100 characters: #15104.

@grunweg, I was going to make the two linter coexist for a period, but the failure on the reference made me decide to remove the older one with the 101 character limit.  Let me know if I forgot to remove/update something.

There's a style exception in `style-exceptions.txt` which you can remove now; looks good otherwise!

Apart from that, he linter now rightfully complains about existing tests - I think that is for the better, but needs some fixing as well.
Thanks for confirming and for the `style-exception.txt` tip!  I removed the exception, hopefully I've cleared up all the tests as well.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15104~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15107~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15111~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
(And I'm a bit surprised be the last commit: did you intend to put it in this PR?)

The last commit is the one about `import`s, right?  I think that the linter should look at the imports also, right?

Let me know if you think that `import`s should be treated differently!

EDIT: it turns out that all headers already complied with the long line linter.

Yes, that was the commit I meant. Let's leave this to a follow-up.
Thanks for persevering all the way, let's land this!
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10102288678/job/27937602279)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10102288678/job/27937602059)
Thanks for rewriting another text-based linter. I pushed a few minor tweaks directly: this looks good to me. The only question is if the limit should be 100 or 101 characters.
No further comments from me - feel free to maintainer merge on my behalf once the dependent PR has landed.
A few small comments. This is really close to landing - thanks a lot for persevering and working your way through all the small details that came up!
I'm a bit torn about this change, but don't feel strongly about this.

Is it the segmentation of the doc-module or actually using the `set_option`?

I haven't actually tried, but I think that keeping a single doc-module block and using `set_option` between the `import`s and the doc-module would trigger the "late documentation" linter...
It is the segmentation - and probably you're right!
Oh the irony.  The other linter now complains about this one!
:see_no_evil:

```suggestion
-- The *argument* of `#guard_msgs` is *not* exempt from the linter.

(perhaps with additional line wrapping)
```suggestion
-- However, the *doc-string* of `#guard_msgs` is exempt from the linter: these are automatically generated, hence linting them is not helpful.
I added this manually, since otherwise the long line linter complains. :smile:
You're unlinting this as it is a commented guard_msg - makes sense.
Are you excepting this because of the #check?

Yes, indeed.

Given that this file is intended as both a test and a tutorial on how to use `fun_prop`, I tried to keep the original formatting.
Why this one?

Most of this file is commented out and it is probably expected to be uncommented once more work on `polyrith` makes it valid again.  Silencing the linter once, instead of on each "offending" segment seemed less invasive.
Optionally, you can write a comment (so future contributors modifying this file will know). Not something I will insist on, though.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: the long line linter as a syntax linter
